body.head.byline: By ELLEN PILIGIAN and LIBBY SANDER; Ellen Piligian reported from Troy, Mich., and Libby Sander from Chicago.

abstract.p: Police capture Anthony LaCalamita, who shot three people, killing one, in his former workplace after being fired; photo (M)

block.p: A man who was fired last week from his job at an accounting firm in suburban Detroit walked into his former office with a shotgun on Monday and shot three people, killing one, before fleeing and leading police officers on a high-speed chase, the authorities said.

The suspect, identified as Anthony LaCalamita, entered the second-floor office of the accounting firm, Gordon Advisors, about 10 a.m. and opened fire, the police said. A 63-year-old woman and two men, ages 47 and 48, were shot, the police said.
A man who was fired last week attacked former co-workers with a shotgun in Detroit, but was apprehended after a high-speed chase.

A man who was fired last week from his job at an accounting firm in suburban Detroit walked into his former office with a shotgun on Monday and shot three people, killing one, before fleeing and leading police officers on a high-speed chase, the authorities said.

The suspect, identified as Anthony LaCalamita, entered the second-floor office of the accounting firm, Gordon Advisors, about 10 a.m. and opened fire, the police said. A 63-year-old woman and two men, ages 47 and 48, were shot, the police said.
The woman, identified by the police as Madeline Kafoury, died at the scene, the authorities said.

The two other victims were being treated at Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak. Ilene Wolff, a spokeswoman for the hospital, said that their families had requested privacy, and that the hospital was not releasing any information about their condition or the nature of their injuries.

Though the police declined to release the names of the two men, The Detroit Free Press identified them as Paul Riva, 47, of Sterling Heights and Alan Steinberg, 48, of Bruce Township. Both are partners in the firm, the newspaper reported.

Mr. LaCalamita, 38, who was still listed on the firm's Web site as a member of its ''professional staff,'' had been dismissed last week, the police said. Though they would not say what his relationship was with any of the victims or what led to the shootings, ''it doesn't appear it was random,'' the Troy police chief, Charles Craft, said.
Officers and witnesses described a chaotic scene immediately after the shooting as workers barricaded themselves in their cubicles and offices.
A few hours later, some employees gathered outside the building but would not speak to reporters.

The three-story office building houses other tenants in addition to the accounting firm, and appeared to have no formal security system, Chief Craft said. He said witnesses told the police that Mr. LaCalamita had walked into the building and into the firm's unlocked suite as though he were concealing something.

Mr. LaCalamita fled in his car before officers arrived, but witnesses took note of the license plate number, the authorities said. About two hours after the shooting, officers received a tip from a motorist in Flint, about 50 miles north of here, on the whereabouts of the car.
Police officers chased Mr. LaCalamita for about 30 miles at speeds of up to 120 miles an hour on Interstate 75 before apprehending him near Bay City.
